elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">Two novel coordination polymers {[Zn(bdc)(btb)](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Cd2(bdc)2(btb)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) were synthesized. Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, a supramolecular isomer of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> [X.L. Wang, C. Qin, E.B. Wang, Z.M. Su, Chem. Eur. J. 12 (2006) 2680], is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges. Coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units. The blue luminescent emission maxima at 420 and 439<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 440 and 455<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were observed in the solid state at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Two novel coordination polymers {[Zn(bdc)(btb)](H2O)5} n  (1) and {[Cd2(bdc)2(btb)(H2O)2](H2O)7} n  (2) were synthesized. Coordination polymer 1, a supramolecular isomer of [Zn2(bdc)2(btb)2](H2O)2 [X.L. Wang, C. Qin, E.B. Wang, Z.M. Su, Chem. Eur. J. 12 (2006) 2680], is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges. Coordination polymer 2 exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd2 units. The blue luminescent emission maxima at 420 and 439nm for 1, 440 and 455nm for 2 were observed in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content:
<ce:figure>
<ce:link locator="fx1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>

<ce:section-title>Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para view="all">The self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and rigid ligand 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) with Zn(II) or Cd(II) give two novel coordination polymers {[Zn(bdc)(btb)](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>). Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, a supramolecular isomer of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> [X.L. Wang, C. Qin, E.B. Wang, Z.M. Su, Chem. Eur. J. 12 (2006) 2680], is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges. Coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units. The blue luminescent emission maxima at 420 and 439<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, 440 and 455<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were observed in the solid state at room temperature.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Abstract

The self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and rigid ligand 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) with Zn(II) or Cd(II) give two novel coordination polymers {[Zn(bdc)(btb)](H2O)5} n  (1) and {[Cd2(bdc)2(btb)(H2O)2](H2O)7} n  (2). Coordination polymer 1, a supramolecular isomer of [Zn2(bdc)2(btb)2](H2O)2 [X.L. Wang, C. Qin, E.B. Wang, Z.M. Su, Chem. Eur. J. 12 (2006) 2680], is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges. Coordination polymer 2 exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd2 units. The blue luminescent emission maxima at 420 and 439nm for 1, 440 and 455nm for 2 were observed in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Open metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely rising attention not only because of their variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications in the fields of catalysis, separation, gas storage, luminescence, magnetism and ion exchange . The key steps in building coordination networks are to rationally design the appropriate ligands and to choose metal ions with suitable coordination geometries. 1,4-Benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), a rigid organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligand, is a good building block for the construction of binuclear metal complexes , 1D , 2D  and 3D  coordination polymers.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Open metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been widely rising attention not only because of their variety of architectures and topologies, but also because of their potential applications in the fields of catalysis, separation, gas storage, luminescence, magnetism and ion exchange . The key steps in building coordination networks are to rationally design the appropriate ligands and to choose metal ions with suitable coordination geometries. 1,4-Benzenedicarboxylate (bdc), a rigid organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligand, is a good building block for the construction of binuclear metal complexes , 1D , 2D  and 3D  coordination polymers.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">“Supramolecular isomerism”, introduced by Zaworotko and coworkers , is the existence of more than one type of network superstructure for the same molecular building blocks and is therefore related to structural isomerism at the molecular level. Bifunctional flexible ligands with conformational flexibility can induce variety of structures and may lead to the formation of supramolecular isomers . The ligands 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives have received a great attention because of their intriguing structures and unique properties . Recently, we reported the crystal structures of a series of transition metal coordination polymers with the flexible bis(triazole) ligands such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane  and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene . 1,4-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb), a long flexible ligand is not well studied . The combination of rigid 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and flexible 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane can construct novel topologies. In order to investigate the influence of the flexibility of the ligand molecule and the synthesis condition on the architecture of coordination polymers, in the present work, two novel coordination polymers {[Zn(bdc)(btb)](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) and {[Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>}<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) were synthesized with the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and rigid ligand 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc). Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, a supramolecular isomer of [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
, is a special 2D (6,3) network. Coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a distorted cubic topology based on dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: "Supramolecular isomerism", introduced by Zaworotko and coworkers , is the existence of more than one type of network superstructure for the same molecular building blocks and is therefore related to structural isomerism at the molecular level. Bifunctional flexible ligands with conformational flexibility can induce variety of structures and may lead to the formation of supramolecular isomers . The ligands 1,2,4-triazole and its derivatives have received a great attention because of their intriguing structures and unique properties . Recently, we reported the crystal structures of a series of transition metal coordination polymers with the flexible bis(triazole) ligands such as 1,2-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)ethane  and 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-ylmethyl)benzene . 1,4-Bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb), a long flexible ligand is not well studied . The combination of rigid 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate and flexible 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane can construct novel topologies. In order to investigate the influence of the flexibility of the ligand molecule and the synthesis condition on the architecture of coordination polymers, in the present work, two novel coordination polymers {[Zn(bdc)(btb)](H2O)5} n  (1) and {[Cd2(bdc)2(btb)(H2O)2](H2O)7} n  (2) were synthesized with the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb) and rigid ligand 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc). Coordination polymer 1, a supramolecular isomer of [Zn2(bdc)2(btb)2](H2O)2 , is a special 2D (6,3) network. Coordination polymer 2 exhibits a distorted cubic topology based on dimer Cd2 units.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 was synthesized by the slow diffusion method in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O medium. The crystal structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>
 shows that each Zn(II) atom displays a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two bdc, and two triazole  nitrogen atoms from two btb ligands (, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig1"></ce:float-anchor>). The bdc ligand exhibits the bis-monodentate coordination mode and bridges two Zn(II) atoms. The distances of Zn(1)⋯Zn(1B) and Zn(1)⋯Zn(1C) separation by bdc are 11.0467(21) and 10.9518(14)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The btb ligand shows the <ce:italic>anti–anti-gauche</ce:italic> conformation. Two btb ligands double-bridge two Zn(II) atoms to form Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> 22-membered rings with a Zn(1)⋯Zn(1A) distance 9.1663(15)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The whole network is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges (, ). Disordered lattice water molecules fill the cavities.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymer 1  was synthesized by the slow diffusion method in CH3OH/H2O medium. The crystal structure of 1  shows that each Zn(II) atom displays a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry, coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two bdc, and two triazole  nitrogen atoms from two btb ligands (,  ). The bdc ligand exhibits the bis-monodentate coordination mode and bridges two Zn(II) atoms. The distances of Zn(1)⋯Zn(1B) and Zn(1)⋯Zn(1C) separation by bdc are 11.0467(21) and 10.9518(14)Å. The btb ligand shows the anti-anti-gauche conformation. Two btb ligands double-bridge two Zn(II) atoms to form Zn2(btb)2 22-membered rings with a Zn(1)⋯Zn(1A) distance 9.1663(15)Å. The whole network is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges (, ). Disordered lattice water molecules fill the cavities.

elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">Coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units. Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from two chelating COO groups of two bdc and one triazole nitrogen atom from btb in the equatorial plane and two oxygen atoms from one water and one bridging carboxylate oxygen atom in the distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry (, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor>). The bdc ligands have two different coordination modes. One is bis-bidentate chelating mode. The other is bis-tridentate bridging mode. Two crystallographically equivalent Cd(II) atoms are bridging by two tridentate bridging carboxylate to give [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] dimer with a Cd⋯Cd distance 4.2714(16)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Each dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit joins six dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units through four bdc and two btb bridges. The Cd⋯Cd separation by bdc bridges are 11.3208(14) and 11.4597(8)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively. Each dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit connects four dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units via four bdc bridges to construct [Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> planar 2D network (). The long btb ligands bridge the planar 2D networks to generate a novel 3D network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, 
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>). The btb shows the <ce:italic>gauche–anti-gauche</ce:italic> conformation with a Cd⋯Cd separation 13.4319(21)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. If the dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> unit is considered as one node, the structure can be viewed as a distorted simple cubic topology with large voids (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig5"></ce:float-anchor>). The network is not interpenetrated though of the large spacious voids. Disordered lattice water molecules are located in the cavity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Coordination polymer 2 exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd2 units. Each Cd(II) atom is coordinated by four carboxylic oxygen atoms from two chelating COO groups of two bdc and one triazole nitrogen atom from btb in the equatorial plane and two oxygen atoms from one water and one bridging carboxylate oxygen atom in the distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry (,  ). The bdc ligands have two different coordination modes. One is bis-bidentate chelating mode. The other is bis-tridentate bridging mode. Two crystallographically equivalent Cd(II) atoms are bridging by two tridentate bridging carboxylate to give [Cd2(COO)2] dimer with a Cd⋯Cd distance 4.2714(16)Å. Each dimer Cd2 unit joins six dimer Cd2 units through four bdc and two btb bridges. The Cd⋯Cd separation by bdc bridges are 11.3208(14) and 11.4597(8)Å, respectively. Each dimer Cd2 unit connects four dimer Cd2 units via four bdc bridges to construct [Cd2(bdc)2(H2O)2] n  planar 2D network (). The long btb ligands bridge the planar 2D networks to generate a novel 3D network ( ,  ). The btb shows the gauche-anti-gauche conformation with a Cd⋯Cd separation 13.4319(21)Å. If the dimer Cd2 unit is considered as one node, the structure can be viewed as a distorted simple cubic topology with large voids ( ). The network is not interpenetrated though of the large spacious voids. Disordered lattice water molecules are located in the cavity.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">Wang and co-workers  synthesized a coordination polymer [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> with a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network, which has the same Zn/bdc/btb ratio (the same molecular building blocks) as <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and is a supramolecular isomer of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> is a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network whereas <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a 2D (6,3) network. The coordination mode of these two coordination polymers is different. Only single btb bridge links two Zn(II) in the former but double btb bridges connect two Zn(II) atoms in the latter. [Zn(bdc)(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>]  has same M/bdc/btb ratio as <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. [Zn(bdc)(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] has a threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network whereas <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a distorted cubic topology based on dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units. The COO groups of [Zn(bdc)(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] have one coordination mode (bidentate bridge mode) but <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> has two different coordination modes (bidentate chelating mode and tridentate bridging mode). [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and [Zn(bdc)(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] are hydrothermally synthesized whereas <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are synthesized by the slow diffusion method in CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH/H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O medium at room temperature. These structural diversities show that the conditions of syntheses play a key role in the formation of the coordination network.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Wang and co-workers  synthesized a coordination polymer [Zn2(bdc)2(btb)2](H2O)2 with a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network, which has the same Zn/bdc/btb ratio (the same molecular building blocks) as 1, and is a supramolecular isomer of 1. [Zn2(bdc)2(btb)2](H2O)2 is a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network whereas 1 is a 2D (6,3) network. The coordination mode of these two coordination polymers is different. Only single btb bridge links two Zn(II) in the former but double btb bridges connect two Zn(II) atoms in the latter. [Zn(bdc)(btb)0.5]  has same M/bdc/btb ratio as 2. [Zn(bdc)(btb)0.5] has a threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network whereas 2 exhibits a distorted cubic topology based on dimer Cd2 units. The COO groups of [Zn(bdc)(btb)0.5] have one coordination mode (bidentate bridge mode) but 2 has two different coordination modes (bidentate chelating mode and tridentate bridging mode). [Zn2(bdc)2(btb)2](H2O)2 and [Zn(bdc)(btb)0.5] are hydrothermally synthesized whereas 1 and 2 are synthesized by the slow diffusion method in CH3OH/H2O medium at room temperature. These structural diversities show that the conditions of syntheses play a key role in the formation of the coordination network.

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">The solid state luminescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at room temperature are studied (). Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals the emission maxima at approximately 420 and 439<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, upon excitation at 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the emission maxima at approximately 440 and 455<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, upon excitation at 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. In comparison, the free btb molecule in solid state displays an emission band centered at about 405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm when excited at 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Solid H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc has emission in the range 400–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for excitation wavelengths between 360 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . The emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be attributed to the emission of mixed ligands (btb and bdc) ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: The solid state luminescence spectra of 1 and 2 at room temperature are studied (). Coordination polymer 1 reveals the emission maxima at approximately 420 and 439nm, upon excitation at 350nm. Coordination polymer 2 shows the emission maxima at approximately 440 and 455nm, upon excitation at 330nm. In comparison, the free btb molecule in solid state displays an emission band centered at about 405nm when excited at 340nm. Solid H2bdc has emission in the range 400-800nm for excitation wavelengths between 360 and 450nm . The emissions of 1 and 2 can be attributed to the emission of mixed ligands (btb and bdc) ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .

elements.content: <ce:para view="all">In summary, two coordination polymers were synthesized by self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) and Zn(II) or Cd(II). Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges. Coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units. In comparison, [Zn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(bdc)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>](H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, a supramolecular isomer of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, has a a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network and [Zn(bdc)(btb)<ce:inf loc="post">0.5</ce:inf>] has a threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network. These structural diversity shows that the synthesis condition (hydrothermal/diffusion method) and the flexible ligand play a key role in the formation of the coordination network. On the basis of this work, further syntheses and structural studies of novel coordination polymers with flexible bis(triazole) ligands are also under way in our laboratory.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In summary, two coordination polymers were synthesized by self-assembly reactions of the flexible ligand 1,4-bis(1,2,4-triazol-1-yl)butane (btb), 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate (bdc) and Zn(II) or Cd(II). Coordination polymer 1 is a special 2D (6,3) network, with six Zn(II) atoms at six corners and four bdc and two double btb at six edges. Coordination polymer 2 exhibits a distorted 3D cubic topology that is built from dimer Cd2 units. In comparison, [Zn2(bdc)2(btb)2](H2O)2, a supramolecular isomer of 1, has a a threefold interpenetrated diamondoid network and [Zn(bdc)(btb)0.5] has a threefold interpenetrated α-polonium cubic network. These structural diversity shows that the synthesis condition (hydrothermal/diffusion method) and the flexible ligand play a key role in the formation of the coordination network. On the basis of this work, further syntheses and structural studies of novel coordination polymers with flexible bis(triazole) ligands are also under way in our laboratory.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at <ce:inter-ref xlink:href="doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.07.025" xlink:type="simple">doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.07.025</ce:inter-ref>.</ce:para><ce:section-title>Supplementary material</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">

elements.clean_text:
Supplementary material

Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:10.1016/j.inoche.2008.07.025.

Supplementary material

   Supplementary figure S1  The coordination environment around the Zn(II) atom of 1.       Supplementary figure S2  Schamatic plot of 2D (6,3) network. The red lines represent the bdc ligand and the thick blue sticks double btb ligands.       Supplementary figure S3  The coordination environment around the dimer Cd2 unit of 2.       Supplementary figure S4  Side view of 2D network constructed by bdc ligands of 2.       Supplementary figure S5  Solid state emissions of 1 and 2.       Crystal Structures  Crystallographic data.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: A solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc (0.033<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was adjusted to approximately pH 6 with dilute NaOH solution. Then btb (0.039<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH was added. This mixture was added to one side of the “H-shape” tube, and Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.060<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.062<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water was added to the other side of the “H-shape” tube. Colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained in 76% yield (0.078<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 83% yield (0.075<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after one month. Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>Zn (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): C, 37.55; H, 5.12; N, 16.42. Found: C, 37.42; H, 5.01; N, 16.29%. Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>): C, 31.77; H, 4.22; N, 9.26. Found: C, 31.65; H, 4.14; N, 9.13%.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1 and 2: A solution of H2bdc (0.033g, 0.2mmol) in 10mL H2O was adjusted to approximately pH 6 with dilute NaOH solution. Then btb (0.039g, 0.2mmol) in 10mL CH3OH was added. This mixture was added to one side of the "H-shape" tube, and Zn(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (0.060g, 0.2mmol) or Cd(NO3)⋅3H2O (0.062g, 0.2mmol) in 20mL water was added to the other side of the "H-shape" tube. Colorless crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained in 76% yield (0.078g) for 1 and 83% yield (0.075g) for 2 after one month. Anal. Calc. for C16H26N6O9Zn (1): C, 37.55; H, 5.12; N, 16.42. Found: C, 37.42; H, 5.01; N, 16.29%. Anal. Calc. for C24H38Cd2N6O17 (2): C, 31.77; H, 4.22; N, 9.26. Found: C, 31.65; H, 4.14; N, 9.13%.

elements.content:
<ce:simple-para view="all">X-ray single crystal diffraction data collection for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (<ce:small-caps>shelxtl-97</ce:small-caps>). Crystal data for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>Zn (1): <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">r</ce:inf>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>107.268(3)°, <ce:italic>V</ce:italic>

<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>65.262(8)°,<ce:italic>V</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>858.57(14)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å<ce:sup loc="post">3</ce:sup>, <ce:italic>Z</ce:italic>

elements.clean_text: X-ray single crystal diffraction data collection for 1 and 2 were performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (shelxtl-97). Crystal data for C16H26N6O9Zn (1): M r =511.80, triclinic,   P   1   ¯    , a =9.3644(19), b =10.929(3), c =12.025(3)Å, α =105.566(3)°, β =106.174(6)°, γ =107.268(3)°, V =1113.5(4)Å3, Z =2, D c =1.527g/cm3, μ =1.162 mm-1, F(000)=532, S =1.080, R =0.0463, wR =0.1236. Crystal data for C24H38Cd2N6O17 (2): M r =907.40, triclinic,   P   1   ¯    , a =9.6427(4), b =9.9392(8), c =9.9832(13)Å, α =86.303(11)°, β =81.118(11)°, γ =65.262(8)°,V =858.57(14)Å3, Z =1, D c =1.755g/cm3, μ =1.320 mm-1, F(000)=456, S =1.092, R =0.0288, wR =0.0914.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>: A solution of H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc (0.033<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O was adjusted to approximately pH 6 with dilute NaOH solution. Then btb (0.039<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH was added. This mixture was added to one side of the “H-shape” tube, and Zn(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.060<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) or Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>·<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.062<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL water was added to the other side of the “H-shape” tube. Colorless crystals of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were obtained in 76% yield (0.078<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and 83% yield (0.075<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g) for <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> after one month. Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>Zn (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>): C, 37.55; H, 5.12; N, 16.42. Found: C, 37.42; H, 5.01; N, 16.29%. Anal. Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">24</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">38</ce:inf>Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">17</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>): C, 31.77; H, 4.22; N, 9.26. Found: C, 31.65; H, 4.14; N, 9.13%.</ce:simple-para>
cln_elements.clean_text: Synthesis of 1 and 2: A solution of H2bdc (0.033g, 0.2mmol) in 10mL H2O was adjusted to approximately pH 6 with dilute NaOH solution. Then btb (0.039g, 0.2mmol) in 10mL CH3OH was added. This mixture was added to one side of the "H-shape" tube, and Zn(NO3)2 ⋅6H2O (0.060g, 0.2mmol) or Cd(NO3)⋅3H2O (0.062g, 0.2mmol) in 20mL water was added to the other side of the "H-shape" tube. Colorless crystals of 1 and 2 were obtained in 76% yield (0.078g) for 1 and 83% yield (0.075g) for 2 after one month. Anal. Calc. for C16H26N6O9Zn (1): C, 37.55; H, 5.12; N, 16.42. Found: C, 37.42; H, 5.01; N, 16.29%. Anal. Calc. for C24H38Cd2N6O17 (2): C, 31.77; H, 4.22; N, 9.26. Found: C, 31.65; H, 4.14; N, 9.13%.

cln_elements.content:
<ce:para view="all">The solid state luminescence spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> at room temperature are studied (). Coordination polymer <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveals the emission maxima at approximately 420 and 439<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, upon excitation at 350<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Coordination polymer <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> shows the emission maxima at approximately 440 and 455<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, upon excitation at 330<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. In comparison, the free btb molecule in solid state displays an emission band centered at about 405<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm when excited at 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. Solid H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>bdc has emission in the range 400–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for excitation wavelengths between 360 and 450<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . The emissions of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> can be attributed to the emission of mixed ligands (btb and bdc) ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">X-ray single crystal diffraction data collection for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> were performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (<ce:small-caps>shelxtl-97</ce:small-caps>). Crystal data for C<ce:inf loc="post">16</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>Zn (1): <ce:italic>M</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">r</ce:inf>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>511.80, triclinic, <mml:math altimg="si1.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mi>P</mml:mi>
<mml:mover accent="true">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>1</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>¯</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:mover>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>, <ce:italic>a</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>9.3644(19), <ce:italic>b</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>10.929(3), <ce:italic>c</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>12.025(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>105.566(3)°, <ce:italic>β</ce:italic>

cln_elements.clean_text:
The solid state luminescence spectra of 1 and 2 at room temperature are studied (). Coordination polymer 1 reveals the emission maxima at approximately 420 and 439nm, upon excitation at 350nm. Coordination polymer 2 shows the emission maxima at approximately 440 and 455nm, upon excitation at 330nm. In comparison, the free btb molecule in solid state displays an emission band centered at about 405nm when excited at 340nm. Solid H2bdc has emission in the range 400-800nm for excitation wavelengths between 360 and 450nm . The emissions of 1 and 2 can be attributed to the emission of mixed ligands (btb and bdc) ligand-to-metal charge-transfer (LMCT) .

X-ray single crystal diffraction data collection for 1 and 2 were performed on a Rigaku Mercury CCD. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined with full-matrix least-squares technique (shelxtl-97). Crystal data for C16H26N6O9Zn (1): M r =511.80, triclinic,   P   1   ¯    , a =9.3644(19), b =10.929(3), c =12.025(3)Å, α =105.566(3)°, β =106.174(6)°, γ =107.268(3)°, V =1113.5(4)Å3, Z =2, D c =1.527g/cm3, μ =1.162 mm-1, F(000)=532, S =1.080, R =0.0463, wR =0.1236. Crystal data for C24H38Cd2N6O17 (2): M r =907.40, triclinic,   P   1   ¯    , a =9.6427(4), b =9.9392(8), c =9.9832(13)Å, α =86.303(11)°, β =81.118(11)°, γ =65.262(8)°,V =858.57(14)Å3, Z =1, D c =1.755g/cm3, μ =1.320 mm-1, F(000)=456, S =1.092, R =0.0288, wR =0.0914.

<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Schematic plot of the 3D network of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The red lines represent the bdc ligands and the blue ones btb ligands. The black lines show the connection of dimer Cd<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> units. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="gr4"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
cln_elements.clean_text: Fig. 4  Schematic plot of the 3D network of 2. The red lines represent the bdc ligands and the blue ones btb ligands. The black lines show the connection of dimer Cd2 units. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.)
